speaker: Rob
text: Hello. Welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob.

speaker: Neil
text: And hello, I'm Neil.

speaker: surf and turf
text: Now, Neil, how do you feel about surf and turf?

speaker: Surf and turf
text: Surf and turf? Love it. What's not to love? Some lobster, a juicy steak – fries on the side. Mmm, delicious.

speaker: Rob
text: Ah, you know what you've done there?

speaker: Neil
text: No, do tell.

speaker: Rob
text: You've got completely the wrong end of the stick.

speaker: Neil
text: I said steak, not stick – a juicy steak.

speaker: surf and turfsurfing and turfing
text: No! Wrong end of the stick. You misunderstood me. I'm not talking about the surf and turf meal, but the online shopping habit of surfing and turfing.

speaker: Neil
text: Oh, my bad – but to be fair, this is quite a new use of this expression, isn't it?

speaker: Surf and turfcheckout
text: Yes, it is. Now, you probably know that 'surfing' is a verb we use for looking at things on the internet. Surf and turf refers to when we go to an online store, select lots of things for our virtual shopping basket but when we get to the checkout, which is the place where we pay for our shopping, we don't actually complete the purchase. We turf out the basket. We abandon it.

speaker: turf outturfed out
text: To turf something out is a phrasal verb for 'throwing something out'. Although it's normally used about people – for example, someone who is behaving badly might be turfed out of a club.

speaker: turfed out
text: Indeed. Well, I'm sure I'll get turfed out of the presenter's union if I don't get to today's quiz question. According to recent research, which items are the most likely to be surfed and turfed? Is it:

speaker: turfed out
text: a)    Books

speaker: turfed out
text: b)    Watches

speaker: turfed out
text: c)    Women's knitwear­­

speaker: turfed out
text: What do you think, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Right, I think... I'm also certain it's a) books.

speaker: Rob
text: Well, we'll find out if you're right later in the programme. Now, this research also revealed that approximately 40% of people have abandoned an online shopping basket in the last year.

speaker: Neil
text: And it was calculated that this meant there was approximately 18 billion pounds worth of lost sales.

speaker: Rob
text: I have to say, I'm a bit sceptical about that figure. I don't trust it. We don't always intend to buy everything we put in our baskets. It's a bit like window shopping. We just browse and find it convenient to put things in our basket to think about later. Have you ever done that?

speaker: Neil
text: Sure. It's a bit like browsing in a shop, isn't it – except you can save items you are interested in to look at later. You might also make a basket in one online store, then go to another to see if you can get the same or similar items cheaper there. So I agree: I don't think that the figure of 18 billion represents a total. Some of that was never intended to be spent – and some would have gone to other stores.

speaker: Rob
text: But there are other reasons we don't complete our purchases. For some it's finding out at the end that there will be a high delivery cost or that paying is very complicated.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, I agree with that. That's so annoying. You spend time collecting all the things in the basket, then find you have to create an account, or you can't use your favourite payment method, or have to pay more to use a credit card and you have to fill out so many details. Sometimes you get so frustrated that you just give up.

speaker: retailersretailers
text: Exactly, and this is a subject that retail expert Clare Bailey discussed in the BBC programme You and Yours. She talks about retailers, which are the businesses that sell things. What does she say 70% of retailers hadn't done?

speaker: retailersout of datefell foul
text: We found that something over 70% of the retailers hadn't invested in the payment process in the last two years, so the technology is really out of date – whereas they have potentially invested in getting us to that page and then they fell foul.

speaker: Rob
text: 70% of retailers hadn't invested in the payment process. They hadn't changed the way people pay online for at least two years.

speaker: out of dateout of date
text: Because online technology develops so quickly, that means that their systems are out of date. Something that is out of date is too old, it's no longer suitable.

speaker: fall foulfall foul
text: She says that companies invest in the shopping experience of their sites but have ignored the checkout process. This is where they fall foul. This is where they make a mistake and get into trouble – where they can lose customers. Right, before we fall foul of the listener, let's have the answer to the quiz. I asked you which items were the most commonly abandoned at the virtual checkout. Was it books, watches or women’s knitwear? So Neil, what did you say?

speaker: Neil
text: I'm pretty certain it's books.

speaker: Rob
text: The answer was actually women's knitwear. Not books, as you thought.

speaker: Neil
text: Ah well, I can't be right all the time.

speaker: surf and turf
text: Some of the time would be nice. Anyway, let's have a look at today's vocabulary. First surf and turf is an expression for online shopping without the actual shopping. You put items in your basket but never actually buy them.

speaker: Neil
text: It's also a delicious meal of seafood and red meat.

speaker: Rob
text: Not if you're a vegetarian, Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: Ah, good point, good point.

speaker: to turf outturfed out
text: The verb to turf out means 'to remove someone from a place or organisation, possibly because they've broken the rules or behaved badly'. For example, if we don't finish the programme on time we might be turfed out of this studio.

speaker: checkoutcheck outcheckout
text: The place where you pay for your shopping, either in a real shop or online is the checkout. That can be a verb as well as a noun: you check out at the checkout.

speaker: retailers
text: The businesses that sell you things are retailers.

speaker: out of date
text: And with hope they don't sell you things that are out of date because that would mean they are past their best; too old to be suitable.

speaker: fall foul offall foul of
text: And finally there was to fall foul of something or someone, which is 'to make a mistake and get into trouble with someone'.
